subject: Cybersecurity
title: The One-Time Pad: The Only Perfect Cipher
description: A micro-lesson that makes The One-Time Pad: The Only Perfect Cipher usable.

hook.text: There exists a cipher that is mathematically proven to be unbreakable. It's almost never used.

buildup.text: A one-time pad XORs each message character with a truly random key that's as long as the message itself.

discovery.text: Claude Shannon proved in 1949 that if the key is truly random, used once, and kept secret, it's perfect.

twist.text: The catch: you need to securely deliver a key as long as every message you'll ever send. That's impractical.

climax.text: The hotline between Washington and Moscow used one-time pads â€” perfect security for imperfect enemies.

punchline.text: Perfect encryption exists. It's just too expensive to use.

quiz.question: Why is the one-time pad rarely used despite being unbreakable?
options: The key must be as long as the message and used only once
